title: South West Trains passengers 'treated worse than cattle' out of London Waterloo
text:
25 shares 2
View
comments
A rail company has apologised for serious disruption to busy services caused by a broken down train, amid complaints that passengers are being treated 'worse than cattle'.
South West Trains services into and out of London Waterloo were hit during the evening peak last night, with packed commuter trains grinding to a halt.
Passengers vented their anger at the disruption, sending messages on social media about having to pay for taxis, questioning how they could claim compensation and revealing how unpleasant it was to stand on crowded trains, even having to lean against toilet doors.
South West Trains services into and out of London Waterloo were hit during the evening peak last night, with packed commuter trains grinding to a halt. Pictured is the display board at Clapham Junction
SWT said a train was damaged near Wimbledon in South London, leaving it stationary for an hour.
A statement said: 'The line between Wimbledon and Raynes Park remained closed to allow for safety inspections to take place and to ensure that no more trains would be damaged when travelling through the area.

'The incident meant that both the main line and the suburban line heading away from London Waterloo were closed through Wimbledon for an extended period during our busiest time in the evening peak.'
Commuters took to Twitter to vent their frustration at the service.
Passengers vented their anger at the disruption, sending messages on social media about having to pay for taxis, questioning how they could claim compensation and revealing how unpleasant being on the train was
Sarah Wade said 'South West Trains are a complete nightmare!' while 'Jen Rachel AM' wrote 'South West Trains - stopping people from getting home since 1996'.
Tanya Lewis, 24, from Wimbledon, told MailOnline Travel: 'My partner was stuck for almost an hour just outside the station [Clapham Junction] and apparently they were told about three different stories regarding the issue by the guard.'
Mick Cash, general secretary of the Rail, Maritime and Transport union, said: 'It is scandalous that while the publicly-owned Network Rail cops multi-million pound fines for performance failures, the private train companies get away without even a rap on the knuckles for failing the travelling public day in and day out.
'It is no wonder that Labour leadership contender Jeremy Corbyn is picking up huge public support for his backing of the renationalisation of the railways when passengers paying thousands for season tickets are treated worse than cattle in the name of private greed.'
